# The Question of Evidence: From Technical to Legal Attribution

The evidence collected to identify the computers and individuals involved in a cyber operation may also be used to determine whether they were acting on behalf of a State. This leads to the question of how such evidence may be used and considered admissible in a judicial proceeding, or more generally in an international dispute, related to a cyber operation.

The development of State activities in cyberspace, notably offensive cyber operations, has led to international disputes between States. To date, a State has neither disputed a cyber operation before an international court or tribunal nor raised the issue before the UN Security Council. Generally, victim States have chosen to respond through extra-juridical measures, such as cyber countermeasures or measures of retorsion.¹ However, there is the possibility that a State, in future, may bring a charge of harmful cyber operations before an international court or tribunal or before the UN Security Council.

Different procedures for the collection, presentation and assessment of evidence exist depending on the international court or tribunal selected and the circumstances of the case.² The assertion presented hereunder is that the International Court of Justice (ICJ) would be the most suitable judicial organ to deal with an international dispute arising from cyber operations conducted by one State against another. Thus, this chapter considers the procedures for the collection and assessment of evidence that may be applied in the event of a case before the ICJ. Before the ICJ, all parties are equal and thus have equal rights to submit and present their legal case. Moreover, each party bears the burden of proof regarding

## 3.1 State Practice on Evidence Relating to Cyber Operations

The nascent State practice on responding to state-sponsored cyber operations seems to demonstrate that States are increasingly aware of the need to support their accusations with evidence proving the facts and the alleged paternity of the cyber operations concerned. This is particularly crucial regarding cyber conduct, as cyberspace offers numerous opportunities to hide or forge the real paternity of a cyber operation, notably by using proxy computer systems or botnets located in other countries. Some perpetrators have even inserted misleading hints into the computer code of a virus in an attempt to shift the blame onto a third party. United States practice on the attribution of state-sponsored cyber operations may be one of the most documented and serves as an interesting benchmark for the topic of this chapter. For many years, the USA did not officially respond to cyber operations targeting their interests, and thus did not disclose publicly any evidence proving the facts and possible attribution. The American subsidiary of the Japanese conglomerate Sony Corporation was hacked and a significant amount of data was stolen from the company. The hackers demanded the cancellation of the planned release of the film *The Interview*, a comedy about the assassination of North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. ## 3.2 Evidence in International Law

Historically, States have used evidence to support their allegations even outside of a judicial proceeding.¹⁴ This has been the practice, for instance, of international fact-finding commissions, such as the ones established after the 2008 armed conflict in Georgia.¹⁵ The development of international justice has strengthened this practice and made the international community demand an increasingly higher standard of proof.

States increasingly rely on international fact-finding commissions following international incidents that may have led to inter-state disputes, and this development is reflected in various branches and aspects of international law. The crash of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 in Ukraine in 2014 offers an interesting case study regarding State practice on the establishment of fact-finding commissions as well as on the collection and assessment of evidence outside of judicial proceedings. This example is also symptomatic of the challenges posed by technical and scientific evidence.

On 17 July 2014, Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 departed from Amsterdam-Schiphol Airport towards its destination, Kuala Lumpur. However, the aircraft never reached its destination having crashed in eastern Ukraine, in the Donetsk region. At that time, this area was still the scene of an armed conflict between the combatants of the People's Republic of Donetsk and the Ukrainian army. There were no survivors among the 283 passengers and 15 crew members. The circumstances of the crash were unclear and conflicting narratives were proposed. Initially,

In law, evidence ‘tends to prove the existence or nonexistence of some fact’.²⁴ In the case of cyber operations, the facts are generally articulated around two main axes: the identification of the cyber operation and its consequences and the attribution of the cyber operation.

As pointed out by the UNGGE in its 2015 report, ‘In case of ICT incidents, States should consider all relevant information, including the larger context of the event, the challenges of attribution in the ICT environment and the nature and extent of the consequences.’²⁵ Indeed, the fact that an investigation relates to a cyber operation does not mean that evidence should be collected solely within cyberspace. Evidence gathered in the real world can also be relevant, even crucial, in determining the facts and attribution of a cyber operation.

Evidence may consist of documentary evidence, physical evidence, expert or witness testimony, and hearsay evidence. This chapter focuses on the two main forms of evidence that may be relevant in the cyber context: documentary evidence and testimonial evidence from experts.

The various texts relating to the procedure and the production of evidence in a proceeding before the ICJ do not contain any specific provision related to digital evidence, with the exception of Practice direction IXbis. ## 3.3.1 Typology of Documentary Evidence That May Be Collected in Relation to Cyber Operations

The majority of evidence that would be produced by a State regarding a cyber operation, both for the purpose of establishing the facts and for attribution, could be in a written form – i.e. documentary evidence – and would therefore not pose any particular procedural problem in proceedings before a court.

However, an important clarification must be made at this stage. This remark concerns only the presentation of evidence and neither its collection and admissibility nor the capacity of judges to assess it. The latter will be analysed later in this chapter.

During the event of a cyber operation, a number of traces are usually left and may be collected as evidence. Most of these traces can be presented in the form of written documents to constitute documentary evidence.²⁸

In the case of a computer virus, the computer code of the virus can be analysed and presented as evidence. Computer codes consisting of multiple lines of code can easily be considered as written evidence.

Additionally, IP addresses may be collected and presented in a cyber-related dispute. These IP addresses may be used to identify the different computers and servers involved in the cyber operation, either because these computers and servers were used for its launch or transit, or

## 3.3.2 The Necessary Caution in the Collection and Assessment of Evidence

As with any evidence, one must proceed cautiously with the collection and analysis of digital evidence. It is essential to involve experts who can not only analyse the data but also explain their conclusions to non-specialists of computer science, such as to the parties and judges involved in a judicial proceeding. This issue will be developed in the section dedicated to experts.

The malware Stuxnet,³⁴ identified in 2010, which physically damaged several centrifuges of an Iranian nuclear plant, and its subsequent investigation, serve as an interesting example. This malware is alleged to have been a joint cyber operation involving the United States and Israel, the purpose of which was to derail the Iranian nuclear programme and force the country to abandon the military dimension of its nuclear ambition. However, neither Iran nor any other State has officially attributed this cyber operation to the United States, Israel or any other State, and no State has claimed paternity for this malware. Stuxnet was first identified in June 2010 by a Belarusian cybersecurity company, VirusBlokAda, and was subsequently analysed by experts from various cybersecurity companies, including Kaspersky and Symantec. The latter published a report detailing the functioning of Stuxnet.³⁵ An important part of this report dug into and analysed the computer code of Stuxnet, and identified two elements that may hint at a potential link between Israel and the malware.

## 3.3.3 The Validity of Unlawfully Collected Evidence

Cyberspace is characterised by the interconnection of computer networks, making it possible to remotely access various connected networks and computer systems. ## 3.4 Expert Opinion Evidence

While ‘evidence’ generally refers to documentary evidence, the importance of expert opinions, especially in disputes involving technical or scientific evidence, should not be underestimated.⁴⁵

There is no universally accepted definition of an expert in the context of an international court or tribunal. A definition can be found in the Agreement between the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea and the Federal Republic of Germany regarding the Headquarters of the Tribunal, which states that an ‘expert’ is ‘a person called at the instance of a party to a dispute or at the instance of the Tribunal to present testimony in the form of expert opinions, based on special knowledge, skills, experience or training’ (Article 1(l)).

In a dispute related to a cyber operation, it is essential to involve experts for two main reasons. Firstly, it is possible that neither the judges nor counsel have the requisite knowledge to understand the technical details of the dispute. Secondly, it is essential that the computer evidence provided by the parties be analysed by qualified experts who can attest to its authenticity and provide the relevant analysis.

In a case before the ICJ, experts can be involved in four different ways: they may be appointed by the parties; the judges may consult them in an informal manner; or decide to involve them in the proceedings; and finally, it is possible for the judges to appoint assessors who sit in on the proceedings but do not have the right to vote.

Conversely, the presentation of technical evidence relating to cyber operations is not particularly challenging, as most of it may be easily presented as documentary evidence.

# The Question of Evidence: From Technical to Legal Attribution
The evidence collected to identify the computers and individuals involved in a cyber operation may also be used to determine whether they were acting on behalf of a State. This leads to the question of how such evidence may be used and considered admissible in a judicial proceeding, or more generally in an international dispute, related to a cyber operation.
The development of State activities in cyberspace, notably offensive cyber operations, has led to international disputes between States. To date, a State has neither disputed a cyber operation before an international court or tribunal nor raised the issue before the UN Security Council. Generally, victim States have chosen to respond through extra-juridical measures, such as cyber countermeasures or measures of retorsion.¹ However, there is the possibility that a State, in future, may bring a charge of harmful cyber operations before an international court or tribunal or before the UN Security Council.

## 3.3.1 Typology of Documentary Evidence That May Be Collected in Relation to Cyber Operations
The majority of evidence that would be produced by a State regarding a cyber operation, both for the purpose of establishing the facts and for attribution, could be in a written form – i.e. documentary evidence – and would therefore not pose any particular procedural problem in proceedings before a court.
However, an important clarification must be made at this stage. This remark concerns only the presentation of evidence and neither its collection and admissibility nor the capacity of judges to assess it. The latter will be analysed later in this chapter.

## 3.3.2 The Necessary Caution in the Collection and Assessment of Evidence
As with any evidence, one must proceed cautiously with the collection and analysis of digital evidence. It is essential to involve experts who can not only analyse the data but also explain their conclusions to non-specialists of computer science, such as to the parties and judges involved in a judicial proceeding. ## 3.3.3 The Validity of Unlawfully Collected Evidence
Cyberspace is characterised by the interconnection of computer networks, making it possible to remotely access various connected networks and computer systems. This feature makes access to digital evidence easier on a technical level. It also facilitates the task of the perpetrator of a cyber operation wishing to erase or blur their tracks. It is indeed relatively easy for them to access the clues they may have left and to move, manipulate or destroy them.³⁸ It is therefore essential for the victim of a cyber operation wishing to seize and secure potential evidence to act as quickly and thoroughly as possible before the perpetrator erases their tracks. For this reason, investigators must act with a certain discretion so as not to accelerate the perpetrator's attempts to modify and remove the evidence they may have left behind.

## 3.4 Expert Opinion Evidence
While ‘evidence’ generally refers to documentary evidence, the importance of expert opinions, especially in disputes involving technical or scientific evidence, should not be underestimated.⁴⁵
There is no universally accepted definition of an expert in the context of an international court or tribunal. In this sense, neither the Statute nor the Rules of Court clarify who may be called as an expert in a case before the ICJ. A definition can be found in the Agreement between the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea and the Federal Republic of Germany regarding the Headquarters of the Tribunal, which states that an ‘expert’ is ‘a person called at the instance of a party to a dispute or at the instance of the Tribunal to present testimony in the form of expert opinions, based on special knowledge, skills, experience or training’ (Article 1(l)).
In a dispute related to a cyber operation, it is essential to involve experts for two main reasons. Firstly, it is possible that neither the judges nor counsel have the requisite knowledge to understand the technical details of the dispute. Secondly, it is essential that the computer evidence provided by the parties be analysed by qualified experts who can attest to its authenticity and provide the relevant analysis.
In a case before the ICJ, experts can be involved in four different ways: they may be appointed by the parties; the judges may consult them in an informal manner; or decide to involve them in the proceedings; and finally, it is possible for the judges to appoint assessors who sit in on the proceedings but do not have the right to vote.

## 3.3.3 The Validity of Unlawfully Collected Evidence
Cyberspace is characterised by the interconnection of computer networks, making it possible to remotely access various connected networks and computer systems. This feature makes access to digital evidence easier on a technical level. It also facilitates the task of the perpetrator of a cyber operation wishing to erase or blur their tracks. It is indeed relatively easy for them to access the clues they may have left and to move, manipulate or destroy them. It is therefore essential for the victim of a cyber operation wishing to seize and secure potential evidence to act as quickly and thoroughly as possible before the perpetrator erases their tracks. For this reason, investigators must act with a certain discretion so as not to accelerate the perpetrator's attempts to modify and remove the evidence they may have left behind.

The procedure for the collection of technical evidence by the victim State from computer systems and networks located within its territory is governed by that State's domestic law. ## 3.4 Expert Opinion Evidence
While ‘evidence’ generally refers to documentary evidence, the importance of expert opinions, especially in disputes involving technical or scientific evidence, should not be underestimated.
There is no universally accepted definition of an expert in the context of an international court or tribunal. In this sense, neither the Statute nor the Rules of Court clarify who may be called as an expert in a case before the ICJ. A definition can be found in the Agreement between the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea and the Federal Republic of Germany regarding the Headquarters of the Tribunal, which states that an ‘expert’ is ‘a person called at the instance of a party to a dispute or at the instance of the Tribunal to present testimony in the form of expert opinions, based on special knowledge, skills, experience or training’ (Article 1(l)).
In a dispute related to a cyber operation, it is essential to involve experts for two main reasons. Firstly, it is possible that neither the judges nor counsel have the requisite knowledge to understand the technical details of the dispute. Secondly, it is essential that the computer evidence provided by the parties be analysed by qualified experts who can attest to its authenticity and provide the relevant analysis.
In a case before the ICJ, experts can be involved in four different ways: they may be appointed by the parties; the judges may consult them in an informal manner; or decide to involve them in the proceedings; and finally, it is possible for the judges to appoint assessors who sit in on the proceedings but do not have the right to vote.

## 3.4.2 'Invisible' Experts Consulted by the Court
The ICJ, like other international jurisdictions, has to deal with disputes involving an important technical dimension requiring some specific expertise. This is especially the case for border disputes. The subject has been analysed by Robert Yewdall Jennings, who notes that:
the Court has not infrequently employed cartographers, hydrographers, geographers, linguists, and even specialised legal experts to assist in the understanding of the issue in a case before it; and has not on the whole felt any need to make this public knowledge or even to apprise the parties.^[46]^
In some cases involving a strong technical dimension, the judges of the ICJ have consulted informal experts to assist them, but these experts were not officially involved in the proceedings. Generally, such experts act as temporary members of the Registry of the Court and their findings are not communicated to the parties or made public.^[47]^

While such consultation of ‘invisible’ experts may be pardonable if the input they provide relates to the scientific margins of a case, the situation is quite different in complex scientific disputes, as is the case here. Under circumstances such as in the present case, adopting such a practice would deprive the Court of the above-mentioned advantages of transparency, openness, procedural fairness, and the ability for the Parties to comment upon or otherwise assist the Court in understanding the evidence before it. These are concerns based not purely on abstract principle, but on the good administration of justice.
A distinction should be drawn between situations in which invisible experts are consulted on technical issues relevant – but not decisive – to the case, and situations in which they may critically influence the outcome of the case. However, this distinction has not yet been made.
The distinction proposed above would be particularly relevant in a dispute relating to a cyber operation. Judges may have recourse to invisible experts to assist them in their understanding of the functioning of the Internet and relevant computer systems, specifically to help them in developing a general knowledge of the subject matter of the dispute. Conversely, it would be desirable for matters related to the evidence provided by the parties, as well as technical problems specifically related to the case, to be dealt with by experts appointed by the Court and taking part in the proceedings. In such cases, as developed below, expert opinions are communicated to the parties who can then comment on them. This would be particularly relevant and important for disputes regarding cyber operations, as the proceedings may involve a large amount of technical evidence, the assessment of which by experts may be crucial.

In a case before the ICJ, it is possible for judges to appoint experts.^[52]^ This possibility is provided for in Article 50 of the Statute of the Court, which states that '[t]he Court may, at any time, entrust any individual, body, bureau, commission, or other organisation that it may select, with the task of carrying out an enquiry or giving an expert opinion'. Article 67 of the Rules of Court clarifies the position regarding the appointment of experts by judges:

If the Court considers it necessary to arrange for an enquiry or an expert opinion, it shall, after hearing the parties, issue an order to this effect, defining the subject of the enquiry or expert opinion, stating the number and mode of appointment of the persons to hold the enquiry or of the experts, and laying down the procedure to be followed. ## 3.4.4 Assessors Appointed by the Court
ICJ judges may appoint assessors, who may sit with the Court but do not have the right to vote. This possibility is opened by Article 30(2) of the Statute of the Court, according to which ‘[t]he Rules of the Court may provide for assessors to sit with the Court or with any of its chambers, without the right to vote’. This provision is clarified by Article 9 of the Rules of Court, which provides that this possibility is available in contentious and advisory cases and that these assessors ‘shall be appointed by secret ballot and by a majority of the votes of the judges composing the Court for the case’. Neither the Statute nor the Rules of the Court specify whether the State Parties are to be involved in the procedure for appointing assessors.
As Giorgio Gaja points out, no assessor has ever been appointed in a case before the ICJ. He argues that there are two reasons for this: firstly, even if they do not have the right to vote, the assessors could be seen as wielding too much influence over the decision of the judges; secondly, the parties and their experts would not be informed and thus they would not be able to comment on the opinions expressed by the assessors.

## 3.5 Concluding Remarks on the Question of Evidence
This chapter analysed the question of evidence in relation to a dispute regarding cyber operations. Such disputes may involve a significant amount of highly technical evidence, the collection and assessment of which by the parties and by the judges, in the case of judicial proceedings, may be challenging. Conversely, the presentation of technical evidence relating to cyber operations is not particularly challenging, as most of it may be easily presented as documentary evidence.
States could, however, be reluctant to make such evidence public during judicial proceedings. Firstly, from the point of view of the State, by revealing the collected evidence, it is likely to give indications about its computing capabilities. Secondly, by publicly disclosing information about a cyber operation, there is a risk that the vulnerabilities exploited by this cyber operation would be taken advantage of by other actors to perpetrate cyber operations. The evidence collected to identify the computers and individuals involved in a cyber operation may also be used to determine whether they were acting on behalf of a State. This leads to the question of how such evidence may be used and considered admissible in a judicial proceeding, or more generally in an international dispute, related to a cyber operation.
The development of State activities in cyberspace, notably offensive cyber operations, has led to international disputes between States. To date, a State has neither disputed a cyber operation before an international court or tribunal nor raised the issue before the UN Security Council. Generally, victim States have chosen to respond through extra-juridical measures, such as cyber countermeasures or measures of retorsion. In the case of a computer virus, the computer code of the virus can be analysed and presented as evidence. Computer codes consisting of multiple lines of code can easily be considered as written evidence.

## 3.3.3 The Validity of Unlawfully Collected Evidence
Cyberspace is characterised by the interconnection of computer networks, making it possible to remotely access various connected networks and computer systems. This feature makes access to digital evidence easier on a technical level. It also facilitates the task of the perpetrator of a cyber operation wishing to erase or blur their tracks. It is indeed relatively easy for them to access the clues they may have left and to move, manipulate or destroy them. It is therefore essential for the victim of a cyber operation wishing to seize and secure potential evidence to act as quickly and thoroughly as possible before the perpetrator erases their tracks. For this reason, investigators must act with a certain discretion so as not to accelerate the perpetrator's attempts to modify and remove the evidence they may have left behind.
One of the main features of cyberspace that affects the seizure of technical evidence in criminal, terrorist and inter-state cases is the transnational dimension of cyberspace. ## 3.4 Expert Opinion Evidence
While ‘evidence’ generally refers to documentary evidence, the importance of expert opinions, especially in disputes involving technical or scientific evidence, should not be underestimated.
There is no universally accepted definition of an expert in the context of an international court or tribunal. In this sense, neither the Statute nor the Rules of Court clarify who may be called as an expert in a case before the ICJ. A definition can be found in the Agreement between the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea and the Federal Republic of Germany regarding the Headquarters of the Tribunal, which states that an ‘expert’ is ‘a person called at the instance of a party to a dispute or at the instance of the Tribunal to present testimony in the form of expert opinions, based on special knowledge, skills, experience or training’ (Article 1(l)).
In a dispute related to a cyber operation, it is essential to involve experts for two main reasons. Firstly, it is possible that neither the judges nor counsel have the requisite knowledge to understand the technical details of the dispute. Secondly, it is essential that the computer evidence provided by the parties be analysed by qualified experts who can attest to its authenticity and provide the relevant analysis.
In a case before the ICJ, experts can be involved in four different ways: they may be appointed by the parties; the judges may consult them in an informal manner; or decide to involve them in the proceedings; and finally, it is possible for the judges to appoint assessors who sit in on the proceedings but do not have the right to vote.

# The Question of Evidence: From Technical to Legal Attribution
The evidence collected to identify the computers and individuals involved in a cyber operation may also be used to determine whether they were acting on behalf of a State. This leads to the question of how such evidence may be used and considered admissible in a judicial proceeding, or more generally in an international dispute, related to a cyber operation.
The development of State activities in cyberspace, notably offensive cyber operations, has led to international disputes between States. To date, a State has neither disputed a cyber operation before an international court or tribunal nor raised the issue before the UN Security Council. Generally, victim States have chosen to respond through extra-juridical measures, such as cyber countermeasures or measures of retorsion.¹ However, there is the possibility that a State, in future, may bring a charge of harmful cyber operations before an international court or tribunal or before the UN Security Council.

## 3.3.3 The Validity of Unlawfully Collected Evidence
Cyberspace is characterised by the interconnection of computer networks, making it possible to remotely access various connected networks and computer systems. This feature makes access to digital evidence easier on a technical level. It also facilitates the task of the perpetrator of a cyber operation wishing to erase or blur their tracks. It is indeed relatively easy for them to access the clues they may have left and to move, manipulate or destroy them.³⁸ It is therefore essential for the victim of a cyber operation wishing to seize and secure potential evidence to act as quickly and thoroughly as possible before the perpetrator erases their tracks. ## 3.4 Expert Opinion Evidence
While ‘evidence’ generally refers to documentary evidence, the importance of expert opinions, especially in disputes involving technical or scientific evidence, should not be underestimated.⁴⁵
There is no universally accepted definition of an expert in the context of an international court or tribunal. In this sense, neither the Statute nor the Rules of Court clarify who may be called as an expert in a case before the ICJ. A definition can be found in the Agreement between the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea and the Federal Republic of Germany regarding the Headquarters of the Tribunal, which states that an ‘expert’ is ‘a person called at the instance of a party to a dispute or at the instance of the Tribunal to present testimony in the form of expert opinions, based on special knowledge, skills, experience or training’ (Article 1(l)).
In a dispute related to a cyber operation, it is essential to involve experts for two main reasons. Firstly, it is possible that neither the judges nor counsel have the requisite knowledge to understand the technical details of the dispute. Secondly, it is essential that the computer evidence provided by the parties be analysed by qualified experts who can attest to its authenticity and provide the relevant analysis.
In a case before the ICJ, experts can be involved in four different ways: they may be appointed by the parties; the judges may consult them in an informal manner; or decide to involve them in the proceedings; and finally, it is possible for the judges to appoint assessors who sit in on the proceedings but do not have the right to vote.

## 3.3.2 The Necessary Caution in the Collection and Assessment of Evidence
As with any evidence, one must proceed cautiously with the collection and analysis of digital evidence. It is essential to involve experts who can not only analyse the data but also explain their conclusions to non-specialists of computer science, such as to the parties and judges involved in a judicial proceeding. This issue will be developed in the section dedicated to experts.
The malware Stuxnet,³⁴ identified in 2010, which physically damaged several centrifuges of an Iranian nuclear plant, and its subsequent investigation, serve as an interesting example. This malware is alleged to have been a joint cyber operation involving the United States and Israel, the purpose of which was to derail the Iranian nuclear programme and force the country to abandon the military dimension of its nuclear ambition. However, neither Iran nor any other State has officially attributed this cyber operation to the United States, Israel or any other State, and no State has claimed paternity for this malware. Stuxnet was first identified in June 2010 by a Belarusian cybersecurity company, VirusBlokAda, and was subsequently analysed by experts from various cybersecurity companies, including Kaspersky and Symantec. ## 3.3.3 The Validity of Unlawfully Collected Evidence Cyberspace is characterised by the interconnection of computer networks, making it possible to remotely access various connected networks and computer systems. This feature makes access to digital evidence easier on a technical level. It also facilitates the task of the perpetrator of a cyber operation wishing to erase or blur their tracks. It is indeed relatively easy for them to access the clues they may have left and to move, manipulate or destroy them.³⁸ It is therefore essential for the victim of a cyber operation wishing to seize and secure potential evidence to act as quickly and thoroughly as possible before the perpetrator erases their tracks. For this reason, investigators must act with a certain discretion so as not to accelerate the perpetrator's attempts to modify and remove the evidence they may have left behind.
One of the main features of cyberspace that affects the seizure of technical evidence in criminal, terrorist and inter-state cases is the transnational dimension of cyberspace.³⁹ Indeed, a cyber operation conducted or sponsored by one State against another will probably transit through computer systems and networks located in third-party States. ## 3.4 Expert Opinion Evidence
While ‘evidence’ generally refers to documentary evidence, the importance of expert opinions, especially in disputes involving technical or scientific evidence, should not be underestimated.⁴⁵
There is no universally accepted definition of an expert in the context of an international court or tribunal. In this sense, neither the Statute nor the Rules of Court clarify who may be called as an expert in a case before the ICJ. A definition can be found in the Agreement between the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea and the Federal Republic of Germany regarding the Headquarters of the Tribunal, which states that an ‘expert’ is ‘a person called at the instance of a party to a dispute or at the instance of the Tribunal to present testimony in the form of expert opinions, based on special knowledge, skills, experience or training’ (Article 1(l)).
In a dispute related to a cyber operation, it is essential to involve experts for two main reasons. Firstly, it is possible that neither the judges nor counsel have the requisite knowledge to understand the technical details of the dispute. Secondly, it is essential that the computer evidence provided by the parties be analysed by qualified experts who can attest to its authenticity and provide the relevant analysis.
In a case before the ICJ, experts can be involved in four different ways: they may be appointed by the parties; the judges may consult them in an informal manner; or decide to involve them in the proceedings; and finally, it is possible for the judges to appoint assessors who sit in on the proceedings but do not have the right to vote.

While such consultation of ‘invisible’ experts may be pardonable if the input they provide relates to the scientific margins of a case, the situation is quite different in complex scientific disputes, as is the case here. Under circumstances such as in the present case, adopting such a practice would deprive the Court of the above-mentioned advantages of transparency, openness, procedural fairness, and the ability for the Parties to comment upon or otherwise assist the Court in understanding the evidence before it. These are concerns based not purely on abstract principle, but on the good administration of justice.⁵⁰ A distinction should be drawn between situations in which invisible experts are consulted on technical issues relevant – but not decisive – to the case, and situations in which they may critically influence the outcome of the case.⁵¹ However, this distinction has not yet been made.
The distinction proposed above would be particularly relevant in a dispute relating to a cyber operation. Judges may have recourse to invisible experts to assist them in their understanding of the functioning of the Internet and relevant computer systems, specifically to help them in developing a general knowledge of the subject matter of the dispute. Conversely, it would be desirable for matters related to the evidence provided by the parties, as well as technical problems specifically related to the case, to be dealt with by experts appointed by the Court and taking part in the proceedings. In such cases, as developed below, expert opinions are communicated to the parties who can then comment on them. This would be particularly relevant and important for disputes regarding cyber operations, as the proceedings may involve a large amount of technical evidence, the assessment of which by experts may be crucial.

## 3.5 Concluding Remarks on the Question of Evidence This chapter analysed the question of evidence in relation to a dispute regarding cyber operations. Such disputes may involve a significant amount of highly technical evidence, the collection and assessment of which by the parties and by the judges, in the case of judicial proceedings, may be challenging. Conversely, the presentation of technical evidence relating to cyber operations is not particularly challenging, as most of it may be easily presented as documentary evidence.
States could, however, be reluctant to make such evidence public during judicial proceedings. Firstly, from the point of view of the State, by revealing the collected evidence, it is likely to give indications about its computing capabilities. Secondly, by publicly disclosing information about a cyber operation, there is a risk that the vulnerabilities exploited by this cyber operation would be taken advantage of by other actors to perpetrate cyber operations. This has been demonstrated by WannaCry and the wave of cyber operations that affected a large number of people, institutions and businesses in May 2017. EternalBlue, the vulnerability exploited by some cyber operations and revealed in the summer of 2016, was obtained from the NSA through a hack by the Shadow Brokers.
